15.98.text:
We're in here every morning between 9 and
10 winding the clocks, and if the clock needs

20.07.text:
a dust then we'll be up here with a brush
doing what I'm doing now.

31.56.text:
Death here strikes the hours, these chaps
here strike the quarters.

39.19.text:
They turn round and each one strikes a different
quarter

42.49.text: and it all works for a nice display.

54.75.text:
Like clockwork, I'm glad to hear it! Still
having problems with the quarter train?

62.99.text:
I was just checking that and it seems to be
free now and it's going all right.

69.16.text: Good. And the angels behaving themselves?

71.25.text: Yes, just wobbling like they normally do but...

73.30.text: that's not doing them any harm.

74.30.text:
Well in 1589 you certainly wouldn't buy a
clock like this just to tell the time.

87.61.text:
It is undoubtedly a demonstration of wealth.
This is a sort of Rolls-Royce level of clocks.

96.01.text:
Imagine you come to my palace and I've just
bought this from Isaac Habrecht in Strasbourg

100.74.text:
in 1589. You're going to look at this clock
and say "Wow! Where did you get that? What

107.83.text: does it do? Let's have a performance."

110.13.text:
And I'm going to take great delight in showing
it to you and demonstrating not only my knowledge

116.73.text: of what it does but also the fineness of it.

120.32.text:
The skills of the engraver in the decorated
panels on the clock. The skill of the clock

125.74.text:
maker himself; who put together this wonderful
machine, which does so much.

135.94.text:
On the hour the figure of death strikes on
the bell to remind you that you've got another

141.30.text: hour nearer to meeting your maker.

147.08.text:
He plays a piece written in 1539 known as
the Vater Unser, which was a setting that

152.68.text:
Martin Luther wrote for the words of the Lord's
Prayer.

158.59.text:
I think it's very interesting that such a
beautiful, very expensive object should take

167.13.text:
because this shouts reformation at you. It
is a mark of the fact that the reformation

173.68.text:
had overtaken Germany and now a great city
like Strasbourg was a Lutheran city.

179.77.text:
The reformation started of course as a rebellion,
a great revolt against the past which tore

186.16.text:
Europe apart. But by the time this clock was
made in the 1580's Lutheranism had arrived.

192.11.text:
It was the mainstream religion of Germany
now, and so the music of Lutheranism was also

200.30.text:
It has a weekly indication showing the days
of the week. It has an annual calendar. It

212.53.text:
has a quarter striking, it strikes the hours
and it plays music.

220.54.text:
This clock is saying "I'm a man of culture,
I'm a man who is interested in the cosmos."

228.01.text:
It's also just fun I think. The sheer intricacy
of it. It's a bit like a very expensive, executive
